Ask HN: Next Steps on Leadership Growth
text:
I currently work at an agency and it's coming up on 10yrs that I've been with the company (actually longer about 10.5yrs started off as consultant) and 10.8 years since the company was started. We just brought a CTO on board which the CEO looked to my approval prior to offering him the role. Prior to bringing the CTO on board the CEO was acting in the role of the CTO with the VP of Tech and myself the VP of Engineering assisting.

During the time the CTO was being interviewed I just so happened to have my review with the CEO and he presented me with a question on my next steps and growth with the company. As the company is growing the CEO is also establishing an org chart that he's been working on for over 6 months.

My understanding of my role as the VP Of Eng is that I am tasked with establishing the engineer practice, hiring of engineers, solving issues at the organizational level and managing other managers/leads etc.

The CEO's vision would be to have people specialize in one area with me being presented the role of "Head of Backend".

The question I'm trying to gain clarity on is what is the difference between VP of Engineering and Head of Backend given that we have multiple engineering disciplines (React Native, Frontend and Backend).

Right now I wear the following hats:

- Lead on projects max of 2 (small PM tasks, full feature coding , PR reviewing, system Architect, direct client engagement among other tasks), consultant of many.

- Part of a team of Sr Engineers to redefine our engineering departments and design practices/work flows(building tools, documentation, best practice / structure)

- Hiring Backend developers, 1:1 and mentoring Solution Architect/Problem solver (may be brought in to help solve full tech solutions no matter the discipline. The issue usually starts as a backend need and then goes into Frontend or Mobile implementation/needs)

The issue I'm having here is how to decide on what my next steps are but also if I choose Head of Backend could that be seen as a demotion or should it be seen as a restructure in limiting the need to wear multiple hats and having a clear career growth path.

title: Easy way to create ML dashboards/apps
text:
Hey Guys,

I have been working on a project to build dashboards right out of my Jupyter notebooks. I used it to create a WSB stock tracker. Would love to get your feedback. You can check out the demo --

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dAl1wgc2pbk

If you want to try us out you can signup at -- https://www.airtorch.io/

If you have any recommendations or suggestions for this tool or for another tool, please let me know because I love working on the site.

Show HN: Designing furniture using the CSS grid
text:
At one point during the construction of my house, we needed designs for the kitchen and bathroom cabinets and a bedroom wardrobe.

I wanted full control of the design process. Doing it in vector illustration software was too painful and it was taking too long. But I didn't have the time to learn any complex CAD tool either.

So I developed a small HTML/JS/CSS tool for designing MDF furniture by writing my own little language that transpiles into a CSS grid layout.

Take a look at the blog post for details: https://alnvdl.github.io/2023/01/07/designing-furniture-usin...

Or go directly to the tool (works best on desktop or tablet): https://alnvdl.github.io/squareplanner/

Ask HN: Do you use a standup desk, and if so, how?
text:
I switched to a standup desk two weeks ago (found a motorized one on sale at Costco with one-touch presets), but finding it harder than I expected to switch to standing. I switched because sitting all day is supposed to be bad for your health, and because I struggle with keeping good posture while sitting, but now I'm finding my lower back hurting and also my hamstrings. Now I'm guessing the hamstrings may be temporary as I get used to being on my feet all day instead of sitting down, but less sure about the lower back. (I'm in my 50s, in good health, good BMI, reasonably good physical shape).

I was wondering how many of you use a standup desk and if so, how do you use it (i.e., full-time, alternate stand/sit every hour, etc.), and any tips or things you learned to make it better.

I did get a rocker pad to stand on (nothing fancy, but has a soft rubber cover with lugs) helps me move around and shift positions. I've had it about a week now.

One thing I'm having a hard time is finding the right position for my "mouse" arm (right arm); I feel pulling in my arm, even though I have the desk at the right height for my keyboard (elbows at about 100 deg).

Is it just a matter of getting used to it? Should I alternate sitting/standing? Any tips for the mouse (other than use keyboard shortcuts more?)

title: See it to believe it?: the role of visualisation in systems research
Ask HN: What would you want in a Linux community?
text:
I'm tempted to start a new community for Linux / BSD enthusiasts, a sort of "LUG 2.0". What would you guys want to see in such a thing?

A few of the ideas I had (please feel free to build them yourself!!):

- a stackoverflow-like area but accessed from command line

- calendar of local tech events (obv you don't need that in Silicon Valley, but elsewhere it's still a thing)

- IRC

- job board

- curated selection of recorded talks and howtos

- ideally, a way to let people try out exotic distros quickly on virtual machines (the problem here is cost).

Anything else...?

Show HN: Detect AI-Generated Content with Our Advanced Text Analysis API
text: I'm launching an API to detect whether text was written by a human or AI. It works with short(ish) text and also longer text. This API could come in handy to detect spam or AI generated content in general from models like ChatGPT or GPT-3. Simply send text to the API and it will return the number of tokens used, probability of the prediction, and prediction of real or fake, as well as individual predictions for smaller chunks of the text. It works best with at least 8 sentences. The API is more or less ready but I'm looking for some Beta testers. Feel free to check out the demo on the website.
